Ser Barristan Selmy spoke up. “Your Grace,” he said, “it is not seemly that the king should ride into the melee. It would not be a fair contest. Who would dare strike you?”
Robert seemed honestly taken aback. “Why, all of them, damn it. If they can. And the last man left standing …”
“… will be you,” Ned finished. He saw at once that Selmy had hit the mark. The dangers of the melee were only a savor to Robert, but this touched on his pride. “Ser Barristan is right. There’s not a man in the Seven Kingdoms who would dare risk your displeasure by hurting you.”
The king rose to his feet, his face flushed. “Are you telling me those prancing cravens will let me win?”
“For a certainty,” Ned said, and Ser Barristan Selmy bowed his head in silent accord.
For a moment Robert was so angry he could not speak. He strode across the tent, whirled, strode back, his face dark and angry. He snatched up his breastplate from the ground and threw it at Barristan Selmy in a wordless fury. Selmy dodged. “Get out,” the king said then, coldly. “Get out before I kill you.”
Ser Barristan left quickly. Ned was about to follow when the king called out again. “Not you, Ned.”

>>179058245
Ah, the rise and fall of G4, the network that promised to bring gamers and geeks the content they craved, but ultimately failed to deliver. It's a classic tale of too much promise and not enough follow-through.
You see, G4 wanted to be everything to everyone and ended up pleasing no one. They tried to appeal to both hardcore gamers and casual viewers, but they didn't have the budget to compete with the big boys in gaming coverage, nor the content to hold the interest of the more casual viewer.
It was like a clown trying to be a tightrope walker, sure it could walk on a rope but could not do it nearly as well as a circus performer. It was always a step behind in technology and games coverage, and the shows they did have were often uninspired or just plain bad.
It was like trying to make a dish with expired ingredients that everyone love, sure it could have been good, but with expired food you cant expect much.
G4 just couldn't keep up with the times and eventually, viewers lost interest and the network lost its way.
It was like a old computer that can not run new games, its fun for a while, but eventually it will be obsolete.

In conclusion, G4's failure was a tragedy for all of us who wanted a gaming and geek-centric network, but sometimes, you just can't make a silk purse out of a sow's ear.

Does anyone remember the like supreme early days of G4?
I remember when Time Warner cable had premium channel samples every couple of days on channel 24. Basically on channel 24 on certain days, that channel would just have one of the premium channels on THAT channel for the day/hours. I assume it was so people could see what that channel had to offer and people may change their cable package and such.

One day it had G4 and this was like 2003, maybe 2004, and on it was some guy in a control battle against either a EverQuest or something else, I don't think it was WoW. The character he was battling was I think a pink Sasquatch with a skull face or a pink rabbit man with a skull face.
And when I say battle, I mean it was a live action guy saying, "You won't get away with this!" and try to press a button but "can't" then it cut to this pink fur'd man with a speech bubble saying something.
I think during it too was some "hillbilly" peasant couple and their squabbles. They too were EverQuest or something characters.
Basically they were making a show by role-playing with MMORPG characters and footage and voicing over them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>179064551
Not bad, but I wonder how relevant that is to shit Cameron wants to say. Eywa and the Na'vi are just "mother nature" and the "noble savage" archetypes more than representations of anything strictly real. The Tulkun, likewise, are idealized whales, reflecting thoughts concerning the intelligence of IRL cetaceans and such. The RDA is just the incarnation of uncaring overpowering greed, the destruction it brings, and how dependent humanity has made itself on the unsustainable. Like a mythologization of the part of us that that finds joy and awe in nature and wishes to live in harmony with it, and the short-sighted selfish impulses that lead us to destroy it.

I don't get the sense it's supposed to be a deeply nuanced portrayal. The whalers must waste most of the whale, because that's the archetypal representation of overhunting an animal to extinction for a particular resource.

Cameron wants to show more good humans and evil Na'vi in 3, so I'm wondering how that'll be relevant to the overall themes. Cameron tends to show scientists in a relatively positive light, at least caring about what they're doing or siding with the Na'vi, so it's already clear he sees a positive side to the kind of technological society his humans represent. But where would Ash Na'vi fit into this?

Just being violent and bloodthirsty doesn't seem like enough. I have no expectations for moral handwringing over chasing off colonists, nor do I see an emotional connection to the overarching themes. Where would the environmental message be there, anyway?

posts.com:
In the books the Ginny romance is far less out of left field than in the movies, though why didn't the "wizards" just cast themselves out of the dullest franchise in the history of movie franchises? Seriously each episode following the boy wizard and his pals from Hogwarts Academy as they fight assorted villains has been indistinguishable from the others. Aside from the gloomy imagery, the series’ only consistency has been its lack of excitement and ineffective use of special effects, all to make magic unmagical, to make action seem inert.

Perhaps the die was cast when Rowling vetoed the idea of Spielberg directing the series; she made sure the series would never be mistaken for a work of art that meant anything to anybody?just ridiculously profitable cross-promotion for her books. The Harry Potter series might be anti-Christian (or not), but it’s certainly the anti-James Bond series in its refusal of wonder, beauty and excitement. No one wants to face that fact. Now, thankfully, they no longer have to.

>a-at least the books were good though

"No!" The writing is dreadful; the book was terrible. As I read, I noticed that every time a character went for a walk, the author wrote instead that the character "stretched his legs."

I began marking on the back of an envelope every time that phrase was repeated. I stopped only after I had marked the envelope several dozen times. I was incredulous. Rowling's mind is so governed by cliches and dead metaphors that she has no other style of writing. Later I read a lavish, loving review of Harry Potter by the same Stephen King. He wrote something to the effect of, "If these kids are reading Harry Potter at 11 or 12, then when they get older they will go on to read Stephen King." And he was quite right. He was not being ironic. When you read "Harry Potter" you are, in fact, trained to read Stephen King.

I recently did a rewatch not of the whole series but a few seasons I could say a lot but i'll try keep it short. The overall story is fine but there's so many plotholes and it feels like a mishmash of writers for each episode because continuity is a bit weird not in an obviously broken way but just some devices are used in some episodes and completely ignored in others even when it would be totally appropriate a big example of this is Aelita's terraforming. Like some people have said the episodes are very repetitive every single one follows the exact same structure of xana attack, time crunch clashing with school, get to lyoko, aelita fucks around being useless until she gets to a tower, return to the past deus ex machina; with some b plot sprinkled in honestly the best parts of the show are when they aren't in lyoko all the slice kf life buts are fun but I do like how they make almost all the action intensive scenes in lyoko so they can cheap out on the animation with 3dcg actually very clevrr. The voice acting is ok for a cartoon kinda lame though and the fight coreography is not too bad either I just wish they learned some cooler moves I swear to god I can hear "laser arrow!" in my sleep. OH also i love how whenever they need music they just use the ending theme it cracks me up everytime serioupsly take note of how many times they use that fucking track when someone has heafphones in or something. Anyway it holds up and its fun.

I remember going to the midnight premier of episode 1 with school friends. We were in year 12. I think everyone was so excited at the time for more star wars that we didn't immediately realise just how bad it was.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>179067626
>Episode 1
Massive hype train, starting at least 6 months before the movie came out. Toys on the shelves, interviews in media, behind the scenes photos in mags. Everyone was on it. Star Wars was crazy popular for my dad's generation, and my thinking at the time was, that the new movies were also being made for the existing, older fans. (And I was more of a trekkie anyway.)

However, after finally seeing the new film, it became clear, that children were the target audience, which was a major bummer. Because there was still cool things in the movie, if you could get past Jar Jar and the pointless death of Maul. Technically the movie was a marvel, with top notch visuals and spearheading CGI. And of course, the delicious audio. I still listen to the soundtrack occasionally.

>Episode 2
My personal favourite of the trilogy, even if the movie is uneven and flawed. I was a teenager at the time, so the romance aspect appealed to me greatly, and I thought Hershlag was very pretty. The fact that Anakin was also older now, helped immensely. They should have never casted Jake Lloyd for the part of Little Ani, or anyone else that young either.

The hype wasn't nearly as strong as it had been with Episode 1, but I think people still mostly liked the movie. The war part at the end drags on, and jumping Yoda started to take the movies into uncanny directions.

>Episode 3
Most of the hype had disappeared, and many people (like myself) just wanted to see the trilogy conclude. And this one is the worst of them all. My best memory of the whole movie (which I've never rewatched, unlike the previous two) is people loudly laughing in the theater, when Anakin turns to the dark side. The scene is supposed to be serious, but literally no one could take it seriously. The whole movie seemed like a bad joke.

>>179067626
Older zoomer here, I was old enough to see Episodes 2 and 3 in the theaters.

I don't remember seeing episode 2 (since I was 4 years old), but I supposedly went with my dad. He says that everyone in the theater went apeshit when Yoda took his lightsaber out to fight Dooku. Honestly the most memorable thing about Episode 2 for me as a kid was Count Dooku's lightsaber. My dad bought two of them and we used to lightsaber fight in the backyard at night so we could see them lit-up.

I saw Episode 3 with my mom and I remember being really scared of the infamous "I have the high ground" scene. We laugh at the acting now, but as a 7-year old, the malice in Anakin's voice sounded genuine to me and it was pretty upsetting. I enjoyed the rest of the movie. It really is the perfect movie for someone at that age. The General Grievous fight/chase was my favorite. I remember thinking the close-up on his eyes was the most realistic CG I had ever seen. I remember the showing I went to was a matinee, so it wasn't a full house and nobody made audible reactions to the movie (at least that's how I remember it).

Not sure if it counts, but I also saw Episode 1 in theaters when they did the 3D re-release in 2011. I had seen the movie before then, but it was the first time my friend had seen it, and he enjoyed it. Re-watching it on the big screen was cool, especially the pod-race.

The best thing about growing up with these movies was really the toys and games. I've played with Star Wars action figures and played the LEGO Star Wars video games for longer than I've seen any of the Star Wars movies combined. It really captured the imagination of me, my brother, and other people our age at the time.
